html: I wonder to what extent the problem is that exit polls are perceived as less a more accurate pre-election poll, and more early results snapshot. Reporting on public polls has done a lot to show uncertainty and teach readers how to interpret. Don’t see the same for exit polls

html: First takeaway: 2018 election polling was generally statistically accurate, or at least directionally so. Makes a compelling argument that exit polls require significantly fewer assumptions, and contain a lot more data, than pre-election polls.
